dt: {bc}feeling or showing great surprise or wonder {bc}{sx|astounded|astounded|}, {sx|amazed|amazed|}

dt.t: … she awoke the next day {wi}astonished{/wi} to find that she suffered no ill effects.
heard the news with an {wi}astonished{/wi} smile

shortdef: feeling or showing great surprise or wonder : astounded, amazed

dt: {bc}to strike with sudden and usually great wonder or surprise

dt.t: They were {wi}astonished{/wi} by the vastness and majesty of the cathedral.
In retrospect, it {wi}astonishes{/wi} me that we avoided a major quarrel for so long.

pt: {sc}surprise{/sc} {sc}astonish{/sc} {sc}astound{/sc} {sc}amaze{/sc} {sc}flabbergast{/sc} mean to impress forcibly through unexpectedness. {sc}surprise{/sc} stresses causing an effect through being unexpected but not necessarily unusual or novel.
{sc}astonish{/sc} implies surprising so greatly as to seem incredible.

pt.t: {it}amazed{/it} by the immense size of the place

pt: {sc}flabbergast{/sc} may suggest thorough astonishment and bewilderment or dismay.

et: probably from earlier {it}astony{/it} (from Middle English {it}astonen, astonien{/it}, from Anglo-French {it}estoner{/it} to stun, from Vulgar Latin {it}*extonare{/it}, from Latin {it}ex-{/it} + {it}tonare{/it} to thunder) + {it}-ish{/it} (as in {it}abolish{/it}) {ma}{mat|thunder:1|}{/ma}
shortdef: to strike with sudden and usually great wonder or surprise
